awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: A Mathematical Theory of Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: CPS: Breakthrough: A Mathematical Theory of Cyber-Physical Systems

The fundamental challenge in cyber-physical systems is the confluence of distinct scientific and engineering models, methods, and tools for cyber and physical systems. Cyber systems are primarily about processing information. Physical systems are primarily about structure and dynamics, the evolution of state in time. This project develops a mathematical theory of cyber-physical systems that provides a formal interface between the cyber and the physical. The intellectual merits of the project are a solid basis for the modeling and design as well as the implementation and verification of cyber-physical systems, and a fruitful connection of the nascent discipline of cyber-physical-systems engineering with standard mathematical practice. The project's broader significance and importance are providing a sound foundation by which cyber-physical system technologies can be assessed, and enabling the discipline of cyber-physical-system engineering to evolve into a mature and durable field of study.

The project builds on the theory of generalized ultrametric semilattices and the fixed-point theory of strictly contracting functions on generalized ultrametric semilattices to develop a cyber-physical domain theory, providing a firm mathematical footing for arbitrary composition and higher-order behavior, formulating the right notion of convergence and continuity for cyber-physical computation, and developing a notion of approximation and effectiveness that allows for a two-way connection between the abstractions of the theory and the realizations of practice. It further applies the theory to a wide range of classic problems of modeling and simulating mixed discrete and continuous phenomena, and extends it to embrace the discrete interventions of a cyber subsystem on its physical counterpart in a cyber-physical system. It also investigates the practical implications of the theory for the implementation and verification of cyber-physical systems by reexamining currently used timed models of computation through the prism of the theory, exploring the extension of programming languages with temporal constructs that are complete over the theoretical abstractions, and integrating the theory in automated and interactive theorem provers to supplement existing model-checking methods that might succumb to the scale of cyber-physical systems.

por.por_cntn:
Cyber-physical systems are engineered systems that include computers but are not themselves, in essence, computers. Example include cars, airplanes, medical devices, trains, robots, computer-controlled chemical plants, and many others.  The essential properties of CPS includes both a cyber part, the functions performed by the computers in the system, and a physical part, the functions performed by everything else. The fundamental challenge in cyber-physical systems is the confluence of distinct scientific and engineering models, methods, and tools for the cyber and physical subsystems.

Cyber systems are primarily about processing information. Physical systems are primarily about structure and dynamics, the evolution of state in time. This project has developed a mathematical theory of cyber-physical systems that provides a formal interface between the cyber and the physical. The intellectual merits of the project are a solid basis for the modeling and design as well as the implementation and verification of cyber-physical systems, and a fruitful connection of the nascent discipline of cyber-physical-systems engineering with standard mathematical practice. The project?s broader significance and importance are in providing a sound foundation by which cyber-physical system technologies can be assessed, and enabling the discipline of cyber-physical-system engineering to evolve into a mature and durable field of study.

The project has contributed fundamental mathematical theorems and, perhaps more importantly, fundamental limitations that constrain what we can say formally about cyber-physical systems. The project developed particular mathematical models, building on the mathematics of generalized ultrametric semilattices and the fixed-point theory of strictly contracting functions on generalized ultrametric semilattices to develop a cyber-physical domain theory, providing a firm mathematical footing for arbitrary composition and higher-order behavior, formulating the right notion of convergence and continuity for cyber-physical computation, and developing a notion of approximation and effectiveness that allows for a two-way connection between the abstractions of the theory and the realizations of practice.

This project applied the theory to a wide range of classic problems of modeling and simulating mixed discrete and continuous phenomena, and extended it to embrace the discrete interventions of a cyber subsystem on its physical counterpart in a cyber-physical system. It also investigated the practical implications of the theory for the implementation and verification of cyber-physical systems by reexamining currently used timed models of computation through the prism of the theory, exploring the extension of programming languages with temporal constructs that are complete over the theoretical abstractions, and integrating the theory in automated and interactive theorem provers to supplement existing model-checking methods that might succumb to the scale of cyber-physical systems.

In addition to these foundational mathematical results, this project has identified some key limitations that will be shared by all possible theories about cyber-physical systems. One such key limitation, stated briefly, is that determinism is incomplete. Specifically, any set of models that is rich enough to encompass Newton's laws of motion (for modeling physical mechanics) and also admits discrete events (for modeling cyber-interactions with those physical components) does not contain its own limit points. One can construct a Cauchy sequence of deterministic models where the limiting model is not deterministic. From a practical perspective, this means any deterministic modeling framework for CPS must admit the possibility of nondeterministic behaviors.

Finally, the project has examined connections between the engineering of cyber-physical systems and foundational theories of interaction and embodiment. These theories from statistical reasoning about causation and from psychology, and hence constitute significant outreach to related disciplines.

The work of this project has received considerable attention, as evidenced by a large number of keynotes and other invited talks in venues ranging widely over various disciplines. The PI has recently given keynote talks at conferences focused on design automation (in Florence, Italy), automata theory (St. Petersburg, Russia), neuroscience (Hannover, Germany), and technology for healthcare (in Halmstad, Sweden). He has also given several keynotes or invited talks in more closely related computer science areas (Hilversum, The Netherlands; Pohang, Korea; Beijing, China; Atherton, USA; Annapolis, USA; and Paris, France);
